Office boy booked for filming women.description: PUNE: An office boy of a software company in Hinjewadi IT Park was booked on Friday for filming the women employees in the washroom. A software engineer (47), from Hinjewadi, spotted a cellphone on recording mode in the washroom. She raised an alarm and the company’s officials called police. Sub-inspector R P Bhawari of the Hinjewadi police said the cellphone was hidden between two tiles in the women’s washroom and switched on its camera. Before the police or company officials could take any action, the office boy grabbed his cellphone and ran away. Police said he was a resident of Parbhani district and had been employed with the company for the past eight months. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Station likely to come up on Dadoji Kond.description: PUNE: Plans are afoot to build Metro station at Dadoji Konddev School in the Kasba Peth area following the project-hit residents’ reluctance to relocate. Terming the stand of the people unwilling to relocate for the Metro project “politically motivated”, Bapat said, “These people were to be shifted to Dadoji Konddev School. A new housing project was to come up there for them. But due to their opposition, we are now reconsidering the move. Instead of constructing the rehabilitation project, we shall build the Metro station at Dadoji Konddev School. A traffic study will be done to facilitate the change,” he said. Bapat said the issues of realignment of the Metro route on Ahmednagar Road were also discussed. He said the option of the underground Metro was being explored but the final call was yet to be taken. He said the matter would be discussed at the level of the Lok Sabha committee. One such committee was formed but it could not complete the work because Parliament was dissolved following the completion of its tenure, Bapat said. The plan to construct a Metro station in the area has been rife with constroversy from the beginning, with residents and traders taking out protests against the project, insisting that it would do damage to their livelihoods. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Free parking impractical, unviable: Mall.description: PUNE: Malls and multiplex managements on Saturday cited security and space aspects for charging parking fee, opposing the resolution to offer free parking to visitors of the Pune Municipal Corporation’s City Improvement Committee. The parking in-charge at a mall told TOI that the charges were decided after much thought to deter visitors from taking undue advantage of the parking space. “We have limited space and parking fee is just a way to deter outsiders (who do not want to visit the mall) from parking here. Also, a lot goes into the maintenance of the parking space, including employing security personnel, parking wardens, housekeeping staff and maintaining fire fighting system, smoke detectors, among others,” he said. Besides, a visit to these establishments revealed that variation in parking fee was quite rampant. When asked about it, the parking in-charge said, “This is bound to happen as these charges are dependent on the location, with those in the prime localities charging a higher fee.” When TOI correspondent visited a mall, the parking attendant said they were charging a ‘parking maintenance fee’ of Rs 30 for the first two hours for four-wheelers and an additional Rs 10 per hour thereafter during weekdays. “During weekends, the charges for four-wheeler parking rises to Rs 50 for the first three hours and an additional Rs 10 per hour beyond the stipulated period,” he said. When asked the rationale behind the rise in fee during weekends, the parking in-charge said, “More people visit the mall during weekends and the rise in parking fee is to ensure that people do not occupy the space unnecessarily. In case a person loses the parking ticket, a flat Rs 100 is charged from him/her.” Another mall representative said, “On weekends (Friday, Saturday and Sunday) and public holidays, we have a progressive parking rule where duration of parking invites the charges. For instance, the parking fee for two hours for a four-wheeler is Rs 50 and Rs 30 for a two-wheeler. For every additional hour over this, Rs 10 is charged. During weekdays, the parking fee for a four-wheeler for more than half an hour is Rs 40 and for a two-wheeler is Rs 20.” Another mall in-charge said if parking was made free, the checking of vehicles would stop. “This will give a free hand to disruptive elements to enter the space undeterred. Even the civic body charges fee for parking on roads. Instead of making parking free, the PMC should ensure a strong public transportation system to reduce the number of vehicles on city roads,” he said. A city-based multiplex owner said there was no provision in the development control (DC) rules to make parking free. “All multiplexes charge fee according to their parking area maintenance cost, location of the establishment and availability of the space. The state government too had earlier passed a similar order but withdrew it in two weeks,” he said. Awais Ansari, admin manager, Pune Central Mall, said the parking charge was Rs 40 for a four-wheeler and Rs 20 for a two-wheeler. “However, this can be redeemed at the end of one’s shopping from the cash counter,” he said. Citizens said malls should not extract money in the name of parking facilities. “Malls should focus on easing it (parking fee) out for legit shoppers and visitors,” Viplav Shukla, a consultant, said. While the proposal to have free parking in the malls might look good on paper, some citizens were worried about the security aspect. “I feel they should have subsidized parking rates and not charge Rs 20-40 as it would ensure vigilance of the security guards on the vehicles parked at these places. What is the guarantee that miscreants would not come and park two-wheelers at such locations?” S Balakrishnan, an entrepreneur, asked. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Vayu\u2019s intensity highest for June s.description: PUNE: Very severe cyclonic storm Vayu, which stopped the monsoon in its track and caused distress evacuation in the coast of Gujarat, recorded the highest intensity for a June storm in the past nine years. This was revealed in the decadal cyclone data provided by the India Meteorological Department (IMD). Even though the IMD said the storm skirted the Saurashtra coast, the system was very likely to move nearly westwards during the next 48 hours. Last time a very severe cyclonic storm hit the Arabian Sea was in June 2010. The storm was christened 'Phet'. "In terms of severity, the last time such a cyclone formed over the north Indian Ocean was in June 2010 (Phet). This one had also come as far as Gujarat. It was the last very severe cyclonic storm over the north Indian Ocean in June, after which there was none until Vayu," A K Srivastava, head, Climate Research Division, IMD, Pune, said. Srivastava said Phet began forming around May 31 as a depression and continued till around June 7 as a system of various intensities, including very severe cyclonic storm. "But that was during the start of the monsoon season. Vayu, meanwhile, occurred after the monsoon set in over Kerala and was still strengthening. Thus it slightly disturbed the monsoon flow. Even though this may not always be the case, but cyclones forming and moving away from the coast tend to disturb the monsoon flow usually," he said. JR Kulkarni, chairman, Indian Meteorological Society (IMS), Pune, said a very severe cyclonic storm in June was rare. "Such type of a system can do either of the two things. If it had moved quickly towards the Oman coast, it may have even caused quick monsoon onset over parts of the south peninsular India and west coast. However, Vayu kept moving northwards along the coast initially. One of its descending limbs over land regions like Maharashtra, Karnataka and Kerala sucked in all the moisture, which is not conducive to the monsoon onset," Kulkarni said. A cyclone expert at the ministry of earth sciences said it was in June 2007 that Super Cyclonic Storm Gonu had formed, which was even greater in intensity than Phet and Vayu. "This means that there are instances when systems with the intensity of a very severe cyclonic storm and above have formed in June in the past and thus it cannot be called unusual. At times they tend to enhance monsoon, while other times they adversely affect it. This time, however, Vayu seems to have had a negative impact on monsoon," he said. Pune cop action against loud hotels, pub.description: PUNE: The crime branch of the Pune police on Friday night filed cases against eight pubs and hotels for playing loud music well after the deadline, disturbing the peace in Mundhwa and Hadapsar. The establishments were playing music on loudspeakers after 10.30pm — the deadline for using them. A team comprising assistant commissioner of police (crime) Bhanupratap Barge, inspector Datta Chavan, sub-inspector Santosh Tasgaon and others were on patrol, passing by the party joints, when they heard loud music. The police filed cases against the outlets under the provisions of the Maharashtra Police Rules. Barge said they would continue the drive on weekends, and hotels and pubs would not be allowed to play loud music after the 10.30pm deadline. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. Pune: Wrong side riding causes woman\u20.description: PUNE: A woman (55) died as she came under the wheels of a truck and her husband was injured after he failed to balance his two-wheeler while avoiding collision with a scooter speeding in from the wrong direction of the road near Chandni Chowk on Saturday night. The Kothrud police said the accident occurred around 10.30pm on the steep slope connecting Chandni Chowk to Paud Road. A resident of the Siddhivinayak Krupa society, Surekha Pradeep Wani was critically injured and was taken to Sassoon General Hospital. Doctors in the hospital declared her dead on arrival. Her husband, Pradeep Wani (64), was injured in his leg while trying to avert the collision. The police have arrested the truck driver for negligent driving. The scooterist who had flouted the rule fled the spot. On Sunday, Wani told TOI that he had gone to a friend’s house in Bavdhan with his wife, their two sons and daughters-in-law for dinner on Saturday. “We usually travel together in car. But we went to Bavdhan on our two-wheelers because one of my sons had bought tickets for a play after the dinner,” he said. Around 10.30pm, Wani and his wife left Bavdhan for home on his two-wheeler. “I was descending the slope near Chandni Chowk to reach Paud Road. I suddenly spotted a man on a white scooter speeding in from the opposite direction towards Chandni Chowk,” he said. “The person was riding along the wrong side of the road, which is not only narrow but is also dangerous because of the steep slope. I started shouting at the scooterist to alert him that he was violating the wrong-side rule. He, however, paid no attention and kept on speeding,” Wani said. “All that I remember that a multi-axle truck was passing by us. I cannot recall what happened at that moment. I felt a jerk in the scooter and my wife fell on the right side of the road. Her left leg and hand came under the wheels of the heavily loaded truck,” he said. The accident survivor said despite all his attempts, he could not remove Surekha out of the truck. “She remained stuck under the wheels of the truck and kept on looking at me helplessly. Someone contacted the police and ambulance,” Wani said. A police team reached the spot and managed to remove Surekha from the spot. She was taken to the Sassoon hospital, where the doctors pronounced her dead on arrival. Kothrud police inspector Shankar Khatke told TOI that the Mumbai-bound truck was also descending the slope. “We have arrested the truck driver,” he said. The left side of the slope that connects Chandni Chowk to Paud Road has been dug up for the ongoing Chandni Chowk flyover work. The road is already narrow and has become more risky, especially during night hours, because of the flyover work. The police have restricted the entry of vehicles from Paud Road to avoid accidents. However, many people violate the rule to avoid a detour to reach Bavdhan. Kothrud traffic branch inspector Ajay Chandkhede said, “A team of Kothrud police has been deployed where the slope connects the bypass during day time. Similarly, a team of Warje police is deployed at Chandni chowk. We are regularly taking action against the people violating the no-entry rule.” Wrong-side driving has become rampant across the city, leading to quite a few accidents across the city (see graphic). Inspector Khatke said as per police commissioner K Venkatesham’s directions, action was being taken against the wrong-side drivers under Section 279 (rash driving) of the Indian Penal Code. If convicted under the section, a driver can be fined Rs1,000 or face imprisonment for up to six months, or both. On June 6, the traffic branch had taken action against 67 motorists for wrong-side driving. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Urmila Matondkar.description: MUMBAI: The Congress on Friday nominated actress Urmila Matondkar and former Lok Sabha speaker Meira Kumar from Mumbai North and Bihar's Sasaram parliamentary constituencies respectively. The party renominated its sitting MP Ranjet Ranjan from Supaul in Bihar, as it released a list of another 12 candidates for the general elections. With this list, the Congress has so far nominated 305 Lok Sabha candidates. Urmila Matondkar to contest from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency on a Congress ticket.… https://t.co/JweKWNh1FN— ANI (@ANI) 1553836382000It also changed its candidate in Uttar Pradesh's Maharajganj by now fielding Supriya Shrinate in place of Tanushree Tripathi, the daughter of jailed politician Amarmani Tripathi, after facing widespread criticism. "The Congress central election committee has approved the candidature of Urmila Matondkar as party candidate to contest the ensuing general elections from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency in Maharashtra," a party statement said. Matondkar had joined the Congress after meeting Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday and had later said that she was "here to stay". Meira Kumar have been contesting from her Sasaram parliamentary constituency for many years but had lost in the 2014 Lok Sabha polls. Apart from Supriya Shrinate, in the list of 12 candidates released by the party, four are from Bihar and seven from Odisha. The Congress also released a list of 20 candidates for Odisha Assembly election. Pimpri, Phugewadi will get first set of.description: PUNE: The Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) will start laying tracks on the completed portions of the viaduct first in Pimpri and Phugewadi. The first consigment of tracks arrived at the Pimpri Metro side from Nagpur on Friday. A MahaMetro official said tracks will be lifted onto the viaduct and installed in the next two weeks. Altogether, 3.2km of viaduct has been completed on the Metro stretch between Pimpri and Phugewadi. MahaMetro said they will construct a cement plinth on the viaduct, on which the tracks will be installed. The tracks are between 18 and 24 metres long, an official said. “The tracks will installed and welded simultaneously to ensure uniformity in the tracks’ level. We plan to lay 2km in one month,” an official said. The viaduct will comprise two sets of tracks — one in each direction. “Both sides will be laid simultaneously. The work will continue during the monsoon and halted only during heavy showers,” the official said. MahaMetro has appointed an agency to lay tracks in the PCMC-Dapodi-Range Hills section and is in the process of appointing a firm to take up the work in the the Vanaz-Garware College-Civil Court portion, where a 1.3km viaduct is ready. “Since the viaduct is ready, we do not see any obstacles ahead. We are starting the work from Pimpri at first, and then from Phugewadi. The work is delicate, but the agency has been told to expedite the work and complete it in within the deadline,” an official said, adding that the total work period for the entire stretch. PCMC-Range Hills, was 18 months and expressed confidence that it would be completed well before that. Around 600 metric tonnes of tracks are expected to arrive in the next few days from Nagpur, where too MahaMetro is executing a Metro project. MahaMetro will float a tender for the remainder. Woman seeks to drop robbery case after t.description: PUNE: Parveen Zulfikar Dingankar, the 45-year woman who had lodged an FIR alleging that two masked men had gagged her, threatened her by putting a knife to her 11-year-old daughter’s throat and fled with Rs 7.5 lakh from her flat in Sarvodaya housing society on May 26, has now filed a plea with the Kondhwa police to withdraw her complaint. The plea was filed on June 11 after the investigation officer asked Dingankar to undergo a polygraph test as her complaint was found to be doubtful during the probe. Prakash Gaikwad, the deputy commissioner of police (Zone IV), confirmed that the complainant has given an application to the senior inspector of Kondhwa police station to withdraw her FIR. “We have asked her to submit an affidavit and she will be referred to a magisterial court for recording her statement under section 164 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. On completion of the procedure, we will take a call and decide on a further course of action,” he said. Senior inspector Anil Patil, the in-charge of the Kondhwa police station, said, “There were several discrepancies in the woman’s complaint. She was twice called for questioning, but she did not give satisfactory answers. We requested her to undergo a polygraph test, but she refused. She then filed an application and requested us to not proceed with the investigation. No incident of house robbery has been reported in the city.” In her application, Parveen Dingankar said, “We are shifting from Pune to our native place. And because of my health issues, travelling problems and as my husband works abroad, we, as a family, have decided to take the case back.” Dingankar, whose phone was switched off, could not be reached for a comment. In her FIR, she had claimed that the robbers were waiting outside her third-floor flat in the society on NIBM Road, in Kondhwa. As soon as she opened the door to keep the trash out at 7.45am, they overpowered her and pushed her inside. Two of her children and her father-in-law were asleep in other rooms. The robbers had allegedly made her close the door and gagged her. They then asked for all the valuables and cash in the house. When she told the robbers that she had nothing to give them, they threatened her with dire consequences. One of them put a knife to her daughter Swaliya’s throat. The girl was in the same room as her but was asleep at the time. The other robber showed Parveen a video clip on his smartphone of other children being hurt and threatened to kill Swaliya. Parveen pleaded with the robbers to spare her daughter. She told them about the cash kept in the cupboard. The suspects made her open the cupboard, remove the cash and pack it in a bag and fled.
